description: From Middle English meten, from Old English mētan (“to meet, find, encounter”), from Proto-West Germanic *mōtijan (“to meet”), from Proto-Germanic *mōtijaną (“to meet”), from Proto-Indo-European *meh₂d- (“to come, meet”).

entries.meaning: (sports) A sports competition, especially for track and field or swimming.
(hunting) A gathering of riders, horses and hounds for foxhunting; a field meet for hunting.
(rail transport) A meeting of two trains in opposite directions on a single track, when one is put into a siding to let the other cross.
(informal) A meeting.
examples: OK, let's arrange a meet with Tyler and ask him.

entries.meaning: (algebra) The greatest lower bound, an operation between pairs of elements in a lattice, denoted by the symbol ∧.

verbs.description: meet (third-person singular simple present meets, present participle meeting, simple past and past participle met)

definitionGroups.group: To make contact (with) while in proximity.

entries.meaning: To come face to face with by accident; to encounter.
examples: Fancy meeting you here! Guess who I met at the supermarket today?

entries.meaning: To come face to face with someone by arrangement.
examples: Let's meet at the station at 9 o'clock.

entries.meaning: To get acquainted with someone.
examples: I'm pleased to meet you! I'd like you to meet a colleague of mine.
I met my husband through a mutual friend at a party. It wasn't love at first sight; in fact, we couldn't stand each other at first!

entries.meaning: To gather for a formal or social discussion; to hold a meeting.
examples: I met with them several times. The government ministers met today to start the negotiations.

entries.meaning: To come together in conflict.
(sports) To play a match.
examples: England and Holland will meet in the final.

definitionGroups.group: To make physical or perceptual contact.

entries.meaning: To converge and finally touch or intersect.
examples: The two streets meet at a crossroad half a mile away.

entries.meaning: To touch or hit something while moving.
examples: The right wing of the car met the column in the garage, leaving a dent.

entries.meaning: To adjoin, be physically touching.
examples: The carpet meets the wall at this side of the room. The forest meets the sea along this part of the coast.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To respond to (an argument etc.) with something equally convincing; to refute.
examples: He met every objection to the trip with another reason I should go.

entries.meaning: To satisfy; to comply with.
examples: This proposal meets my requirements. The company agrees to meet the cost of any repairs.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To balance or come out correct.
examples: In this instance he has chosen an accountant. I suppose that it will be possible for an accountant to make the figures meet.

entries.meaning: To perceive; to come to a knowledge of; to have personal acquaintance with; to experience; to suffer.
examples: The eye met a horrid sight. He met his fate.

entries.meaning: To be mixed with, to be combined with aspects of.

description: From Middle English mete, imete, from Old English ġemǣte (“suitable, having the same measurements”), from the Proto-Germanic *gamētijaz, *mētiz (“reasonable; estimable”) (cognate with Dutch meten (“measure”), German gemäß (“suitable”) etc.), itself from collective prefix *ga- + Proto-Indo-European *med- (“to measure”).

entries.meaning: (archaic) Suitable; right; proper.
